description: The African elephant is the largest land mammal, known for its intelligence and social structure. Conservation: Poaching for ivory and habitat loss are major threats; conservation efforts include anti-poaching patrols and protected areas.

Snow leopards are elusive big cats adapted to cold mountainous regions. Conservation: Main threats include poaching and prey depletion; conservation programs involve community-based monitoring and anti-poaching measures.

Sumatran orangutans are critically endangered primates found in the forests of Sumatra. Conservation: Habitat destruction and illegal pet trade are major threats; conservation includes forest protection and rehabilitation programs.

Axolotls are critically endangered amphibians known for their regenerative abilities. Conservation: Threatened by habitat loss and pollution; conservation includes captive breeding programs and habitat restoration.
Cowan's Mantella is a small, brightly colored frog native to Madagascar. Conservation: Habitat destruction threatens its survival; efforts include captive breeding and habitat protection.

The Chinese giant salamander is the world's largest amphibian. Conservation: Critically endangered due to overharvesting and habitat degradation; conservation involves breeding programs and habitat restoration.

Green sea turtles are marine turtles found in tropical and subtropical waters. Conservation: Threatened by fishing, habitat loss, and pollution; conservation includes nesting site protection and fisheries regulation.
Komodo dragons are the largest living lizards, native to Indonesian islands. Conservation: Threatened by habitat loss and tourism; conservation includes protected parks and breeding programs.
Orinoco crocodiles are critically endangered and native to South America. Conservation: Threatened by hunting and habitat loss; conservation includes captive breeding and habitat protection.
Great white sharks are large predatory fish found worldwide. Conservation: Vulnerable due to overfishing and finning; conservation involves fishing regulations and marine protected areas.
Atlantic Bluefin tuna are large, fast-swimming fish. Conservation: Currently least concern but historically overfished; conservation involves catch quotas and sustainable fisheries.
White sturgeons are long-lived freshwater fish. Conservation: Endangered due to habitat modification and overfishing; conservation involves habitat protection and restocking programs.

Monarch butterflies are migratory insects known for their long-distance travel. Conservation: Habitat loss and pesticide use threaten populations; conservation includes habitat restoration and milkweed planting.
Neomariania scriptella is a rare moth species. Conservation: Endangered due to habitat destruction; conservation includes habitat monitoring and protection programs.

The American burying beetle is critically endangered and helps recycle nutrients. Conservation: Threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation; conservation includes captive breeding and reintroduction programs.
The bald eagle is a large bird of prey native to North America. Conservation: Populations have recovered due to habitat protection and pesticide bans.
Kakapos are nocturnal, flightless parrots critically endangered in New Zealand. Conservation: Conservation efforts include intensive monitoring, predator-free islands, and captive breeding.
The Philippine eagle is a critically endangered bird of prey. Conservation: Main threats include deforestation and hunting; conservation includes habitat protection and captive breeding programs.
